def: used to indicate the place where someone or something is
used to indicate the person or thing toward which an action, motion, or feeling is directed or aimed
used to indicate something that is being tried or attempted

dt: used to indicate the place where someone or something is

dt.t: We're staying {it}at{/it} a hotel.
The kitchen is {it}at{/it} the back of the house.
He was sitting {it}at{/it} the table.
They left for Cambridge early and arrived {it}at{/it} [={it}in{/it}] Cambridge before noon.
The party will be {it}at{/it} Susan's house. = The party will be {it}at{/it} Susan's.
Ann works {it}at{/it} [={it}in{/it}] a library.
We met {it}at{/it} a party.
They live {it}at{/it} opposite ends of town.
They met {it}at{/it} [={it}on{/it}] a street corner in a town.
{ldquo}Is your father {it}at{/it} home?{rdquo} [=is your father home?] {ldquo}No, he's working late {it}at{/it} the office.{rdquo}
She met us {it}at{/it} the door.
He was standing {it}at{/it} [=next to] the window.
There were 200 people {it}at{/it} the wedding. [=200 people attended the wedding]
Their older son has graduated, but their younger son is still {it}at{/it} school. [=is still attending school]
Who was {it}at{/it} the controls when the accident occurred?

snotebox: The word {phrase}at{/phrase} is used in speech in e-mail addresses.

snotebox.t: {ldquo}Can I e-mail you?{rdquo} {ldquo}Sure. Our e-mail address is ‘comments {it}at{/it} Merriam-Webster dot com.’{rdquo}

snotebox: In writing, the symbol @ is used instead.

dt: used to indicate the person or thing toward which an action, motion, or feeling is directed or aimed

dt.t: She pointed her gun {it}at{/it} the target.
He's angry {it}at{/it} his brother.
His anger is directed {it}at{/it} his brother.
She shouted (words of) abuse {it}at{/it} me.
He looked directly {it}at{/it} me.
They laughed {it}at{/it} him.
She grabbed {it}at{/it} my arm. [=she tried to grab my arm]
He poked {it}at{/it} his food.

dt: used to indicate something that is being tried or attempted

dt.t: I made an attempt {it}at{/it} persuading him to go.
I took a shot {it}at{/it} doing it myself. [=I tried to do it myself]
They laughed {it}at{/it} my joke.
She's furious {it}at{/it} how slowly the investigation is proceeding.

dt: used to indicate the cause of an action, feeling, etc.

dt.t: I was greatly surprised {it}at{/it} [={it}by{/it}] the result. [=the result surprised me greatly]
He enlisted in the army {it}at{/it} his father's urging. [=because his father urged him to]
She visited the museum {it}at{/it} my suggestion.
They came here {it}at{/it} our invitation.
You can act {it}at{/it} your own discretion.
He's very serious when he's {it}at{/it} work. [=when he's working]
children who are {it}at{/it} play [=children who are playing]
She's good {it}at{/it} (playing) chess. [=she plays chess well]
I'm bad {it}at{/it} cooking. [=I'm a bad cook, I do not cook well]
She's doing very well {it}at{/it} her studies.

dt: used to indicate a situation or condition

dt.t: I'm not {it}at{/it} liberty to discuss that.
{it}at{/it} rest
two nations that are {it}at{/it} war
people who are {it}at{/it} risk
He is now {it}at{/it} peace.

dt: used to indicate position on a scale or in a series

dt.t: The temperature is {it}at{/it} 90 degrees.
He was driving {it}at{/it} almost 80 miles an hour.
They sell {it}at{/it} [={it}for{/it}] a dollar a dozen. [=each dozen costs one dollar]

dt: used to indicate an age or time

dt.t: He plans to retire {it}at{/it} (age) 65.
He called us {it}at{/it} (about/exactly) 9 o'clock on July 24.
{it}at{/it} dawn/noon/sunset/night
I still think of her {it}at{/it} certain moments/times.
He was president of the company {it}at{/it} (the time of) his death.

dt: used to indicate the method by which something is done

dt.t: The property was sold {it}at{/it} auction.

dt: used in phrases like {phrase}at best{/phrase}, {phrase}at worst{/phrase}, etc., to indicate a possible result or condition that is considered best, worst, etc.

dt.t: The company will make a small profit {it}at best{/it} this year. [=it is not possible that the company will earn anything better/more than a small profit]
We might be 5 or 10 minutes late {it}at worst{/it}. [=we will not be more than 5 or 10 minutes late]
We should arrive by noon {it}at the latest{/it}. [=we should not arrive later than noon]

dt: used in phrases like {phrase}at its best{/phrase}, {phrase}at its worst{/phrase}, etc., to indicate that something or someone is as good, bad, etc., as possible

dt.t: This is baseball {it}at its best{/it}.
He's often rude, and last night he was {it}at his worst{/it}.
I didn't expect her to have started working yet, but she was already (hard) {it}at it{/it} when I arrived. [=she was already working (hard) when I arrived]
My neighbors are always arguing, and they were {it}at it{/it} again last night. [=they were arguing again last night]
Since we're cleaning the kitchen, we should wash the floor {phrase}while we're at it{/phrase}. [=we should wash the floor when we clean the kitchen]
{ldquo}I'm going to the store to buy a newspaper.{rdquo} {ldquo}{it}While you're at it{/it}, could you get some milk?{rdquo}

shortdef: —used to indicate the place where someone or something is
—used to indicate the person or thing toward which an action, motion, or feeling is directed or aimed
—used to indicate something that is being tried or attempted

stems: from one minute to the next

def: {bc} a unit of time equal to 60 seconds {bc} one 60th of an hour
{bc} a brief period of time
{bc} the distance that can be traveled in a minute

dt: {bc}a unit of time equal to 60 seconds {bc}one 60th of an hour

dt.t: Bake the cake for 25-30 {it}minutes{/it}.
We waited for several {it}minutes{/it}, but no one came to the door.
He can run a six-{it}minute{/it} mile. [=he can run a mile in six minutes]
I saw him a {it}minute{/it} ago.
Dinner will be ready in just a few {it}minutes{/it}.
One {it}minute{/it} it was sunny, the next it was pouring rain.
Could I have a {it}minute{/it} of your time? = Do you have a {it}minute{/it}? = Could I speak to you for a {it}minute{/it}? [=could I speak to you briefly?]
I'm coming, just give me a {it}minute{/it}. [=wait for me]
It was an excellent show. I enjoyed every {it}minute{/it} of it. [=I enjoyed all of it]
I'll explain that {phrase}in a minute{/phrase}. [=shortly, soon]

dt: {bc}the distance that can be traveled in a minute

dt.t: My house is just a few {it}minutes{/it} from here.

dt: {bc}an official record of what was said and done in a meeting

dt.t: The secretary read the {it}minutes{/it} of the last meeting.
The secretary took the {it}minutes{/it} [=recorded in writing what happened] during the meeting.

dt: {bc}one of 60 equal parts into which a degree can be divided for measuring angles

dt.t: 42 degrees and 30 {it}minutes{/it}

dt: If something could happen ({phrase}at{/phrase} ) {phrase}any minute{/phrase} ({phrase}now{/phrase} ), it could happen very soon.

dt.t: The bus should be here {it}any minute now{/it}.
I'm expecting a phone call {it}any minute{/it}.
Things could change {it}at any minute{/it}. [={it}at any moment{/it}]

vrs.va: from one minute to the next

dt.t: Things kept changing {it}from minute to minute{/it}. [={it}from moment to moment{/it}]

dt: used to tell someone to wait or to stop for a brief time

dt.t: {ldquo}Aren't you finished yet?{rdquo} {ldquo}{it}Hold on a minute{/it}. I'm almost done.{rdquo}
{it}Hang on a minute{/it}—I didn't hear you. Could you repeat what you said?

dt: used to express surprise or disbelief

dt.t: Hey, {it}wait a minute{/it}! That's not what you said yesterday!
I did {it}not{/it} believe her {it}for one minute{/it}. = {it}Not for one minute{/it} did I believe her. [=I never believed her]
Please call me {it}the minute{/it} you get home.
I knew {it}the minute{/it} (that) I saw it that I had to have this dress.
Stop it {it}this minute{/it}!
I have to have the report {it}this minute{/it}.
The buses were on time {it}to the minute{/it}.

dt: {bc}within a very short amount of time

dt.t: We called an ambulance and it arrived {it}within minutes{/it}.

shortdef: a unit of time equal to 60 seconds : one 60th of an hour
a brief period of time : moment
the distance that can be traveled in a minute

def: {bc} made to be used in the home
{bc} happening at someone's home
{bc} not employed outside the home

dt: {bc}made to be used in the home

dt.t: She uses an {it}at-home{/it} blood test to monitor her blood levels.
{it}at-home{/it} exercise equipment
{it}at-home{/it} entertainment
one of the star's rare {it}at-home{/it} interviews
an {it}at-home{/it} [=(more commonly) {it}stay-at-home{/it}] mother/father

shortdef: made to be used in the home
happening at someone's home
not employed outside the home

def: {it}chiefly US{/it}, {it}formal{/it}

dt.t: John Smith, {it}Attorney at Law{/it}

shortdef: lawyer—used chiefly as a title

def: {bc} looking or seeming cheap or poor and dirty or worn

dt: {bc}looking or seeming cheap or poor and dirty or worn

dt.t: We got a room at a {it}down-at-the-heels{/it} [={it}dingy{/it}, {it}seedy{/it}] motel.
a {it}down-at-heel{/it} traveler

shortdef: looking or seeming cheap or poor and dirty or worn

def: {bc} not comfortable or relaxed {bc} nervous or embarrassed

dt.t: Their stares made us (feel) {it}ill at ease{/it}.
He seemed {it}ill at ease{/it} when we spoke with him.

shortdef: not comfortable or relaxed : nervous or embarrassed

def: {bc} staying at home to take care of a child instead of working somewhere else

dt: {bc}staying at home to take care of a child instead of working somewhere else

dt.t: a {it}stay-at-home{/it} mom/dad

shortdef: staying at home to take care of a child instead of working somewhere else

def: {bc} to blame (someone) for something wrong or illegal {bc} to say that someone is guilty of a fault or crime

dt: {bc}to blame (someone) for something wrong or illegal {bc}to say that someone is guilty of a fault or crime

dt.t: He was unjustly {it}accused{/it}.
He was {it}accused of{/it} stealing the money.
His children have {it}accused{/it} him {it}of{/it} neglect.
You can't {it}accuse{/it} him {it}of{/it} being rude: he's always extremely polite.
She has been {it}accused of{/it} murder. = She {phrase}stands accused of{/phrase} murder.
No one could ever {it}accuse{/it} him {it}of{/it} being overly modest. [=he is not modest]

utxt.t: She deserves the chance to meet/confront her {it}accuser{/it}.
She gave him a very {it}accusing{/it} look.
The governor {phrase}pointed an accusing finger at{/phrase} the legislature [=said the legislature was to blame] for failing to approve her budget.

shortdef: to blame (someone) for something wrong or illegal : to say that someone is guilty of a fault or crime —often + of —sometimes used humorously

stems: more than a passing acquaintance with

def: {bc} someone who is known but who is not a close friend
{it}formal{/it} {bc} the state of knowing someone in a personal or social way {bc} the state of knowing someone as an acquaintance
{bc} knowledge about something

dt: {bc}someone who is known but who is not a close friend

dt.t: Is he an {it}acquaintance{/it} of yours? [=have you met him?]
She ran into an old {it}acquaintance{/it} at the grocery store.
My wife and I met through a mutual {it}acquaintance{/it}. [=a friend introduced us to each other]
a casual {it}acquaintance{/it}
friends and {it}acquaintances{/it}

dt: {bc}the state of knowing someone in a personal or social way {bc}the state of knowing someone as an acquaintance

dt.t: our family's close {it}acquaintance{/it} with our neighbors
It's a pleasure to {phrase}make your acquaintance{/phrase}. [=(less formally) it's nice to meet you]
She {phrase}made the acquaintance of{/phrase} [=she met] a man from the city.
She {phrase}struck up an acquaintance with{/phrase} a man from the city.
a doctor {phrase}of my acquaintance{/phrase} [=a doctor that I know]
He seemed cold {phrase}on/at first acquaintance{/phrase} [=when I first met him], but later I realized that he was just shy.
He seemed cold at first, but {phrase}on closer/further acquaintance{/phrase} I realized that he was just shy.
She has only a nodding/slight/superficial {it}acquaintance with{/it} the facts of the case. [=she knows only a little about the facts of the case]
He has {phrase}more than a passing acquaintance with{/phrase} wine. [=he knows a lot about wine]
While he has some {it}acquaintance with{/it} the subject, he is not an expert.

utxt.t: An {it}acquaintanceship{/it} grew between the two men.
Her long {it}acquaintanceship{/it} [={it}acquaintance{/it}] with sorrow began when her young husband died.

shortdef: someone who is known but who is not a close friend
the state of knowing someone in a personal or social way : the state of knowing someone as an acquaintance
knowledge about something—+ with

def: {bc} beyond the basic level
{bc} far along in a course of progress or development: such as
{bc} having developed more than others

dt.t: {it}advanced{/it} mathematics
She's taking an {it}advanced{/it} course in English. = She's taking a course in {it}advanced{/it} English.
The school has courses for elementary, intermediate, and {it}advanced{/it} students.
The book explains both basic and {it}advanced{/it} techniques.
The job requires someone with an {phrase}advanced degree{/phrase}. [=a degree (such as a master's degree or a PhD) that is higher than a bachelor's degree]

dt: {bc}far along in a course of progress or development: such as

dt.t: a highly {it}advanced{/it} civilization [=a modern civilization]
an {it}advanced{/it} society

dt: {bc}having or using new and modern methods

dt.t: {it}advanced{/it} technology
technologically {it}advanced{/it} weapons
The system has many {it}advanced{/it} features.

dt: {bc}having reached a bad state or condition

dt.t: The house was in an {it}advanced{/it} state of disrepair. [=the house was in very poor condition]
The disease is in an {it}advanced{/it} stage.
an {it}advanced{/it} form of cancer

dt: {bc}far along in a process of aging

dt.t: She began painting {phrase}at an advanced age{/phrase}. [=she began painting when she was old]
He is rather {phrase}advanced in age/years{/phrase}. [=rather old]
a man/woman {phrase}of advanced age/years{/phrase} [=an old man/woman]

shortdef: beyond the basic level
far along in a course of progress or development: such as
having developed more than others
